Comments (adn_ints):
Lexical source: 'head' – General comments: POSS-: possessor prefixes (col.II)
-tʂə̀-: verbal reflexivization strategy
POSS-xə̀: 'POSS-head'
xatà probably related to -xə̀
-t°': ATTR
-tà: possibly related to locative suffix -ta

Lexical source: vetë < PIE sue-ti (REFL-?); other intensifier: (PRO) vetë – General comments: verbal reflexivization strategy: V + nonactive person endings (medium): -(h)em, -(h)esh, -(h)et
probably stressed reflexive possessive as competing strategy for: vetë PSM PSR ('own')
edhé në se: 'and if that'

Lexical source: 'head'; other intensifier: ras-POSS(-ART) (NP/PRO); ras-POSS; stressed PRON-ART; PRO(-ART); gəll-POSS ('in person'); qəl: variant of gəll; gəll-POSS: obligatory reflexive marker in PP –General comments: bägäzza eðð-POSS: 'with his own hand/might/power'
yä-gäzza: 'that he possessed'
yä-ras-: variant of yägäzza
also possible: yä-gäzza ras-
yəh rasu: 'this same one, the very same'
bä: preposition with a wide range of meanings (e.g. locative, instrumental)
-m: 'also, even'

Lexical source: nafs- 'soul', 'spirit'; other intensifier: ʔayn in MSA in an adnominal use
lexical source of ʔayn: 'eye'
b-ruuħ-POSS ('by-REFL-POSS'); ruuħ-: 'spirit' – General comments: bi: instrumental marker (requires genitive complement)

Other intensifier: ink'-POSS; anj-amb: 'personally'; ink'ə also used inclusively in the sense of 'too' – General comments: -s, -d: possessive suffixes for 1st and 2nd person
REFL/INT probably derived from the personal pronoun
DEF: ə, except before vowels: then n
the reason why the reflexive marker optionally combines two different stems of INT/REFL is unclear

Lexical source: e-w: possibly < logophoric pronoun, da: emphatic particle; other intensifier: e-wa-da also used inclusively;e-wa-da can be used in anti-comitative contexts ('alone') – General comments: in-šur-da is the ergative of e-w-da
e-w-da: PRON.CASE.NUMBER-GENDER-EMPH
e-wa alone is a logophoric pronoun
-da is an emphatic particle
in-: oblique masculine ew-stem
-šu-: masculine oblique case
-r-: gender marker possessum

Lexical source: deictic pronominal/unknown; other intensifier: for 1st and 2nd person: 1/2SG: PRON.1/2SG-eu-CASE – General comments: buru: 'head'
(bere: be: PRON, re: GEN)
RECIP: elkar: each other (case marked)
-k: ERG
probably there is a 2nd AVE strategy with ERG reflexive

only human referents – General comments: intensified NPs are always subjects, though not necessarily in the nominative case (for dative subjects, cf. ex. 51)
AVE: nije-CASE may be reduplicated (cf. ex. 52)
nije-r ('own') precedes its head NP; alternative expression for nijer : apan, which is restricted to human possessors

Lexical source: PIE *sem 'one' (?); other intensifier: lično 'personally', cf. lice 'face' – General comments: sam: also 'alone'; cf. samo 'only'
in PPs, 1st and 2nd person non-refl. pronouns occur in reflexive function in spoken Bulgarian
refl. clitics: se (ACC), si (DAT)
General comments: ge: linking particle/attributive marker

Lexical source: Latin 'PRO-met ipse-SUPERLATIVE' – General comments: mateix can precede or follow the NP. When it precedes the NP, it has the meaning 'the same'.
Reflexivity is expressed by means of clitic (es) or non-clitic (si) pronouns
es is only used for third person and when the reflexive is a direct or indirect object
regular object pronouns are used with first and second person. In PPs si(+mateix) alternates with PRON-mateix
Only animate referents; lexical source:máʔá ('very', 'exact') – General comments: máá-POSS varies according to person and number (the relevant clitic is used)

Lexical source: possibly 'my-hand'; other intensifier: wel PRO (only high rank reading)
-neʔwia:n
-ixkoiya:n –

Only human referents; lexical source: neʔ: 'own', kɨ: pronominal stem – General comments: -win: body;
-neʔkɨ: pronoun, may not be adjoined to NPs (*Juan ñe'kɨ)
naytyumɨ: < nay-tumɨ 'RECP-one')
-neʔ-kɨ: ~ 'that of his own'
General comments: mig, dig (os, jer): 1st/2nd person (plural) in reflexive contexts identical to normal pronouns

General comments: zich: reflexive marker with typically self-directed verbs (wassen 'wash', scheren 'shave')
under certain circumstances, zich can be bound by a non-c-commmanding antecedent (cf. example 547)
zichzelf: reflexive marker with typically other-directed verbs (haten 'hate', kritiseren 'critizise')
1st/2nd person (plural) in reflexive contexts identical to normal pronouns

Other intensifier: personally (adnominal); alone, by x-self (adverbial exclusive) – General comments: adnominal: 1/2: PRO POSSPRO-self
 3: NP PRON(OBJ)-self
General comments: itse can be used with inanimate NPs and object NPs: AVE is zero-marked for nominative, just like the citation form of ADN: U: exact vowel depends on vowel harmony

Other intensifier: en personne (adnominal) ('personally') – General comments: animate NPs take PRO même
inanimate NPs may as well take only même
pronominal arguments take only même
PRO: non-clitic pronouns (moi, toi, lui, elle, nous, vous, eux, elles)
soi: non-clitic reflexive, only in impersonal constructions
reflexive se is not used in PPs; simple non-clitic pronouns are used instead (therefore arguably (partial) identity of AVE and REFL?)

General comments: féin can be doubled
féin adjoins to nominals; it may also be attached directly to independent pronouns or conjugated pronominal forms (sinn féin: we ourselves)
fhéin: variant of féin
pronouns inflect for person, gender, number
pronoun is obligatory unless nominal is inanimate (?)

Other intensifier: selber (free variant of selbst)
(höchst)persönlich (restricted to humans with a high social rank), leibhaftig, höchstselbst
allein (anti-comitative); von selbst/von allein (anti-causative, anti-initiative)

Lexical source: 'own' – General comments: articles and adjectives inflects for gender, number, case
REFL: 3 strategies
  • 1. nominal: o eaftó mu: citation form (NOM, MASC); eaftó is inherently MASC; Modern Greek has no proper possessive pronouns; genitive forms of personal pronouns are used.
  • 2. middle voice verb forms
  • 3. lexical derivation: prefix: afto- plus (2); (2) alone is ambiguous (weak strategy)

Other intensifier: svayam, svatah and nij are Sanskrit loans used to express anti-causative meaning ('by itself') and AVE; khud: (cf. Persian xod) – General comments: Adnominal: only with nominals that have subject properties
etymology of pote (competing analyses):
a) svah-tah: reflexive-ablative;
b) atman 'soul';
c) pottaa 'cloth'
There is also a 'literary reflexive pronoun' nij (cf. Mistry 2000: 367f.)
alternative expression for 'own': meLe

Lexical source: 'bone' – General comments: citation form of -atsm-: etsem
hitpa'el: verbal strategy with middle semantics
be-: instrumental clitic preposition ('in', 'with')
Exclusive: use of be- is colloquial
AVE: be- is probably obligatory
refl: also hitpa'el conjugation (middle semantics)

Other intensifier: xud (cf. Persian xod ), svayam (< Sanskrit svah-tah) – General comments: apnee aap: citation form
aap: also used as a honorific pronoun, 3.SG/PL pronoun, reflexive pronoun
svayam: of Sanskrit origin
xud/khud: Urdu, colloquial Hindi (cf. Persian xod)
apnee: REFL.OBL; light vs. heavy reflexive roughly corresponds to verbal vs. nominal reflexivization strategy
aap: NOM of REFL

Lexical source: 'seed' – General comments: suffixing <é> to mag yields 'mine', 'yours' etc.
There is a set of derivative affixes that form reflexive verbs from agentive ones

General comments: sjálf- inflects for case, gender, number
sig inflects for case

Lexical source: 'alone'; sen: 'one'; other intensifier: sendiri-sendirian (reduplicated); seorang diri ('alone') – General comments: data are Riau Indonesian
sendiri seems to be used when emphasis is put on the reflexive object;
the reflexive object is in focus
Lexical source: Latin -met ipsim- (superlative of ipse); other intensifier: in persona 'in person'

Only human referents; other intensifier: jitai (for inanimate referents) – General comments: jishin often occupies the position of the topic/case-postpositions (ga, wa)
if it co-occurs with wa, this yields a contrastive topic construction
further reflexivisation strategy: ziko- + verb
jibun-de: anaphor + instrumental postposition

taan: only with animate referents; lexical source: Vedic Sanskrit tman ('vital breath', 'one's own person'); other intensifier: [NP/PRO] PRO-CASE-ee – General comments: -ee: emphatic focalizer
taan: must be bound by a sentence-mate antecedent or logophoric centre, but requires verbal reflexive -koLLu when referring back to a co-argument
taan: only third person
-koLLu: middle marker/verbal reflexive
alternative expression for 'own':swanta
Other intensifier: jineken – General comments: sisasa: 'alone' (anti-comitative); reflexive bana is also used in anti-causative and anti-assistive contexts

Lexical source: 'body' – General comments: -ay: emphatic element
the reflexive paan is derived from the Vedic tman 'vital breath, one's own person'
in Modern Kashmiri paan also means 'body'
paan: light reflexive strategy
panun paan: heavy strategy
Only animate referents; lexical source: ubu-POSS;ubu: preposition 'from, by'; other intensifier: PRON-nyine: 'alone' (~adv exclusive) – General comments: APPL (applicative): -ir/-er

Only human referents; lexical source: sin: 'body'; other intensifier: cachey (for non-human reference); tangsin (2nd person pronoun used for an honoured third-person) – General comments: increasing locality requirement for reflexives: caki > casin > cakicasin; jikjob: ’with one’s body’

Lexical source: cf. Arabic ðaat ('self'); other intensifier: nda POSS.PRO bomo: 'by x-self' (lit.: 'with POSS.PRO head') – General comments: the variant jaatir is used chiefly in the definite form ending in di
reduplication is possible (jaati-jaati(r))
PRO huneyno: 'by oneself'; huna: 'life';
bomo: 'head' (heavy reflexive)
ŋgu: light reflexive
1st and 2nd person: regular pronouns are used as reflexive markers
light reflexives are identical in form to logophoric pronouns and are also used as reflexive possessive pronouns
wala: also means 'or'
additional reflexive strategy: ŋgu bomo ('extra heavy')

Lexical source: < is-pse ('DEM -emphatic element'; cf. rea-pse 'indeed', 'in the thing itself'); other intensifier: -met (ego-met 'I myself') – General comments: in the first and second person, the common pronouns me (1st) and te (2nd) are used as reflexive pronouns
scalar focus particle also vel ('or')

Lexical source: < 'husband' (MASC), 'wife' (FEM) – General comments: pat- inflects for case, gender, number
there is a verbal reflexive -si which covers a range of functions similar to the reflexive suffixes in Slavic languages
sàvo is a third person reflexive pronoun (1st and 2nd person: màno, tàvo);
pàts is also used in prenominal position in the sense of 'exactly', 'just'
pàts can express 'the same' (Senn 1966: 205)
pàt as an inflecting particle occurs after locative adverbials or between preposition and NP in the sense of 'just', exactly' etc.
sávo is also used as possessive genitive

Lexical source: 'body'; other intensifier: (NP) mihitsy; in general, mihitsy 'indeed' is used with full NPs, and tena 'body' with pronouns (Charles Randriamasimanaga, p.c.); irery 'alone' – General comments: tena is incorporated into the verb when used as a reflexive marker (cf. Zribi-Hertz & Rajaonarisoa 1999)
ny tena-POSS: can be long-distance bound (unlike incorporated tena, which can only be locally bound)
adverbial intensifier is not formally identical to adnominal intensifier; instead, a focus construction with the focus construction marker no is used
ihany: 'only'; no: focus construction marker
own: focus construction with no

Lexical source: tanne < taan-ee; taan: anaphoric element, -ee: emphatic element; other intensifier: PRO-ee; tannattaan: < tanne-aal + taan 'INT-INSTR + taan' (Engl. 'by oneself') – General comments: tanne is used in combination with personal pronouns
taan expresses reflexivity in the third person
taan inflects for number and case (cf. Asher, R.E. & T.C. Kumari 1997: 265)
tanne is invariant
-koLLuka: verbal affix (middle marker, cf. Kannada), which often cooccurs with tanne

Lexical source: nifs: 'breath' (cf. Arabic nafs: 'soul'); other intensifier: (PRO) stess (< Italian stesso); lil-PRON + stess; ruh ('soul') – General comments: lil-: object marker
there is a set of detransitivising medium markers (prefixes): t-, n-, nt-

Only animate referents; lexical source: 'nose'; other intensifier: bĕnshēn (adnominal; inanimate referents; cannot be used with agentive verbs)
bĕnrén (adnominal; only human referents)
qīnshŏu (‘(with) own hand’; adverbial exclusive)
qīnyăn (‘(with) own eyes’; adverbial exclusive)
qīnkŏu (‘(with) own mouth; adverbial exclusive)
qīnĕr (‘(with) own ears; adverbial exclusive)
qīnbĭ (‘(with) own brush, in one’s own handwriting’; adverbial exclusive)
qīnzì ‘personally’ – General comments: ATTR: attributive marker -de; long-distance bound use of zìjĭ is possible
own: also qīnshēn (firsthand experience), qīnshēng
Lexical source of reflexive: 'again'
General comments: <N->: nasalizing prefix (reflexive marker/middle voice)

Lexical source: end-eeun: 'exactly, precisely' (ADV), 'real, very' (ADJ); other intensifier: POSS-unan(-penn) (< unan 'one'), also '(NP) alone'
NP zoken (or only scalar reading of zoken?) – General comments: en em: uninflected preverbal particle; verbal reflexive en em can probably cooccur with intensifier POSS-unan (?)

General comments: the intensifier may either precede or follow the head NP
if it precedes, it shows definite inflection; if it follows, it occurs in its indefinite form
on the use of seg (selv) cf. Swedish sig själv

Other intensifier: mataa POSS.PRO ('head'); qofaa ('only, alone') – General comments: This page is about the Afaan dialect of Oromo as described by Griefenow-Mewis (2001)
ofii is also used as a reflexive pronoun when emphasis is desired
Harar Oromo: reflexive forms are ifíi and íf

Lexical source: < Old Persian *xwēš; other intensifier: šaxsan 'personally, in person'
nafs- (cf. Arabic)
xiš, xištan are possessive intensifiers ('own')

Lexical source: ba: 'with'; mudarə: 'head'; other intensifier: təguwayə ('personally')
kəðarə ('by itself')

Lexical source: Proto-IE *sem 'one' (?) – General comments: sam- inflects for case, gender, number
as an adverbial-exclusive intensifier it is always in the nominative
Lexical source: < Lat. -met ipsimus/a; other intensifier: próprio (originally 'own'); sozinho ('alone'), also adverbial intensifier

Other intensifier: xud-CASE (cf. Persian xod)
aap-hii 'INT-EMPH' for English 'by itself'
aap can also be used as an intensifier standing by itself – General comments: there is also a compound verb construction involving the explicator/auxilliary verb laiNaa 'to take' which is used to express reflexivity
General comments: there is no genuine reflexive form (pronominal form followed by emphatic a is used)

Lexical source: îns: 'individual' + unstressed genitive(/dative) pronoun; other intensifier: chiar (also: 'even') – General comments: se/şi are phonologically reduced when preceding an auxiliary (se a > s-a)
Lexical source: Proto-IE *sem 'one' (?); other intensifier: ličnyj ('personally') – General comments: sam and sobstvennyj: inflect for gender, number, case

Other intensifier: reduplicated pronouns: ìníní ('I myself'), ìwéwé ('you yourself'), íyèyè ('he himself');
PRO/NP pachá-POSS; PRON-égà 'PRO alone' (cf. comments) – General comments: égà is the common form in the Zezuru- and Manyika-dialects; in the Kangara-dialect, ógà is more common
APPL: infix -ir-
NC: nominal class marker
paradigm of mèné:
1SG ìní ndó-mèné: I myself
2SG ìwé wó-mèné: you yorself
3SG íyè wó-mèné: s/he herself/himself
1PL ìsú tó-mèné: we ourselves
2PL ìmí mó-mèné: you yourselves
3PL ívò vó-mèné: they themselves
zvi-: reflexive prefix
Lexical source: Proto-IE *sem 'one' (?); other intensifier: osobno: 'personally' – General comments: sam and vlastné inflect for gender, number, case
Lexical source: cf. Arabic nafs ('soul'); other intensifier: qudh-POSS, laft-POSS – General comments: is is invariant

Lexical source: 'head' – General comments: NP/PRO yinmé: can be analysed as a possessive construction (PSR PSM)
possessive pronouns are identical in form to common personal pronouns
du: reflexive marker
intensifier yinmé is optionally used to reinforce reflexivity

Lexical source: Latin -met ipsim- (superlative); other intensifier: mismísimo (superlative of mismo)
in persona ('in person')
propio/a (or. 'own') – General comments: mismo and propio inflect for gender and number

Lexical source: < Proto-Germ. *selba; other intensifier: personligen ('in person') – General comments: Intensifier:
själv inflects for gender and number; when it precedes its head NP, the definite declension class is used, and when it follows the indefinite declension class
Reflexives:
in the first and second person the regular pronouns are used in reflexive contexts
self is added to sig only in the context of verbs denoting typically self-directed activities

Other intensifier: agayu-POSS (agayu: 'head') – General comments: agayu-POSS: restricted to referents of high social rank
PRO nit: nit does not inflect

Other intensifier: PRO/ANPH-aa (approximately equivalent to -ee) – General comments: ANPH: taan (referentially defective, requires local antecedent)
PRO: avan (referentially independent)
intensified pronouns: avan-ee, taan-ee
tan is the genitive of taan
-ee: emphatic element, semantically relatively unspecific
NP-ee often has a scalar meaning ('even NP...')
kuDa: 'too, even'; for 'even' emphatic intonation is used

Only human referents; lexical source: sie: 'one'; other intensifier: belaha (only used for persons occupying a high rank); < vel yaha 'very he' – General comments: -siel: also 'alone'; cf. sie 'one'; basically used as an adverbial intensifier

General comments:
  • wuž is an anaphor with antecedents in the same clause, the same sentence, or even within the discourse
  • different forms of wuž according to nominal class and case: wuž, žu, že, již
  • wuže: wuž (wuž-ERG wuž-ABS): 'double reflexive'; the first wuž takes the case of the agent, the second one of the patient; the choice between the light and the heavy reflexive depends on "whether a target of reflexivization is a core or an oblique argument of the verb" and "whether a situation described is inwardly or outwardly oriented" (Lyutikova 2000: 242)
  • wuž alone may be long-distance bound

Lexical source: 'just'; other intensifier: orungu-POSS – General comments:
  • intensifier is usually used in cleft constructions with a nominalized relative clause and possessive marking (cf. ex. 370)
  • the intensifier alaʔa probably exhibits the same semantics as Breton end-eeun, Mixtec máá- and Zapotec la-gahk
  • orungu-POSS: orungu- means 'body'

Other intensifier: yalnız: 'alone', can also mean 'without any help' – General comments:
  • -POSS indicates person and number
  • kendi- can be reduplicated to express intentionality
  • the middle marker -In has a reflexivizing function with typically self-directed verbs and is also a detransivizer (cf. Kornfilt (1997). Turkish. London: Routledge, p. 157)
  • kendi can be reduplicated (AVE + REFL)
    the verbal reflexive requires a subject antecedent (cf. Kornfilt 1997: 141)

Only animate referents; lexical source: -tuk: 'alone'; other intensifier: mismo (borrowed from Spanish) – General comments: The dialect described is the one of San Andrés (cf. Delgaty, Alfa Hurley y Agustín Ruiz Sánchez (1978). Diccionario Tzotzil de San Andrés con Variaciones Dialectales. México: Instituto Lingüístico de Verano).
The adverbial exclusive intensifier takes up a preverbal position:
(TOP) -tuk V (NP.ABS) (NP.ERG)

Lexical source: bopp: 'head'; ci: 'with'; other intensifier: rekk: 'alone' – General comments: ci bopp-POSS: 'with head-POSS'
mooy: emphatic subject construction
-u, -ku: verbal reflexive strategies

Lexical source: aleyn ('alone'); other intensifier: gufe (adnominal, adverbial) – General comments: afile is borrowed from Hebrew (afilu)
gufe is contextually restricted

Lexical source: fún: 'for'; ara: 'body' (ara is also a reflexive marker); other intensifier: pàápàá (adnominal; also 'especially', 'even') – General comments: before -(:`)mi and -(:`)rɛ/-ɛ the preceding vowel receives a low tone (<`>)
gaan: 'exactly, really, actually'

General comments: PRO ta: 'that which belongs to PRO' (mine, yours etc.)
special reflexive only in the third person
the third person reflexive is phonologically identical to the pronoun of the second person

Lexical source: bee: prep. 'with'; hoore 'head'; other intensifier: koʔe, tigi – General comments: adnominal construction: NP/(PRO) P hoore POSS.PRO; the intensifier is linked to the head NP by some preposition: in some dialects this preposition is gam ('because of'; cf. the paradigm below), and in others bee ('with')
there is also a verbal middle voice with paradigms varying according to tense and mood distinctions
tigi: also means 'exactly'
alternative own: POSS.PRO halal

Probably not with inanimates
kad'ai 'alone, only' is possible with inanimates ('by itself'); lexical source: kâi-: 'head'; other intensifier: kad'ai: 'alone, only' – General comments: <r>: alveolar flap; <rr>: alveolar trill
LNK (bound linker): -n-; expresses adnominal relationship
IND.LNK (independent linker): na/ta
paradigm of intensifiers:
dà: 'with'
own: also NP-LNK IND.LNK kâi-LNK-POSS (emphatic, 'very own')
scalar focus particle koo: often with negative polarity

Lexical source: 'one'; other intensifier: mpenjá (also 'even', 'indeed'); bobɛ́lɛ́ ('alone') – General comments: -mí-: verbal reflexive, fully productive
both intensifiers (mɔ́kɔ́ and mpenjá) are basically equivalent; according to Guthrie (1966), mpenjá is preferred in combination with reflexives and mɔ́kɔ́ elsewhere (Guthrie 1966: 50)
scalar focus particle: also atâ

Lexical source: -enye: 'having, possessing'; other intensifier: moyo wangu ('soul my'), nafsi yangu ('soul my'); cf. Arabic nafs- – General comments: ji-: verbal reflexivization strategy
NC: nominal class marker
paradigm of -enyewe for NC1 (mainly human):
1SG: (mimi) mw-enyewe
2SG: (wewe) mw-enyewe
3SG: (yeye) mw-enyewe
1PL: (sisi) w-enyewe
2PL: (ninyi) w-enyewe
3PL: (wao) w-enyewe
Other intensifier: free pronoun plus corresponding (non-reflexive) pronominal clitic – General comments: -tju/-nku (cf. the paradigms below) adjoin to NPs/pronouns.

Lexical source: dodoc might be a reduplicated form of the reciprocal marker d-oco-b (3SG.OBJ-DIFF.SBJ-3SG.SUBJ) (J. Roberts, p.c.) – General comments: dodoc only attaches to personal pronouns;
DIFF.SBJ: different subject (switch-reference system)

Lexical source: hundi ('breath, soul, life'); other intensifier: da: 'exactly' (emphatic particle stressing the precise referential or spatiotemporal correctness of the preceding constituent, Heath 1999: 265) – General comments: in a local context (coreferential co-arguments), the compound reflexive is regularly used (ŋga boŋ); the light reflexive ŋga is chiefly used in long-distance bound contexts (coreference of clause- or sentence mates that are not co-arguments
both the intensifier and the reflexive derive from body-part nouns, but from different ones (hundey< hundi 'breath, soul, life'; boŋ: 'head')
nda: 'with'
AVE is expressed as 'with + heavy reflexive'/'with x's head'
hinne, hinna also means 'alone, only, immediately'
alternative adv. exclusive intensifier: hinne, hinna

General comments: there seems to be no semantic (near-)equivalent to intensifier constructions in Chamorro
reflexivity can also be signalled by simple pronouns, i.e. na maisa optionally precedes or follows the pronoun in reflexive-marking
maisa also means 'alone'
na is a linker used in attributive constructions
Only animate referents; lexical source: tav-: 'head'; -it: instrumental marker; -on: ?; other intensifier: tv-it, tav-ad – General comments: tav-: 'head'; -it: instrumental;
– General comments: reflexive constructions with POSS-muan are often avoided, and reflexivity is indicated by means of an intransivtiising suffix (-a).
Lexical source: < iimaat 'body'

Lexical source: Spanish mismo (< Latin -met ipsimum) – General comments: sarili: also 'individual'
the etymology of sarili is unclear
sa is a preposition, ari means 'property'
General comments: is immi- etymologically related to (contained in) nammineq?

General comments: the suffix -ni is additive and has both a non-scalar ('also, too') and a scalar reading ('even')
the scalar reading can be made more explicit by adding the particle kwaz, which is originally a converb of the verb kwa 'be under/among' (cf. Haspelmath 1993: 237)

Lexical source: 'man/woman', 'husband/wife' – General comments: reflexive forms: savẽs, savo (GEN), sáu (DAT), savè (ACC), savimì (INSTR), savyjè (LOC); pàt (invariant particle), pàts/patì used as a noun (see lexical source) inflects for number and case.

Other intensifier: swayam (cf. Hindi); POSSPRO + maTuku + PRO (maTuku: 'as for...') – General comments: pronouns (PRO): tan- (referentially defective anaphor; requires local antecedent)
-kon: verbal reflexive or middle voice

General comments: light reflexives: he: (ACC), hôu (GEN), hô:i (DAT); heavy reflexives (third person): he:autón (ACC), he:autoû (GEN), heautô: (DAT); paradigm of intensifiers (MASC): autós, autoû, autô:; the simple reflexive he: is confined to referring back to antecedents from higher clauses (can be used only logophorically); in a local context, the complex reflexive he:auto- has to be used; the intensifier may either follow or precede the NP it combines with
Lexical source: < Spanish mismo; other intensifier: -kurhi (little or no difference to -kuarhe) – General comments: misimu may be used to reinforce the verbal reflexivization strategy

Only animate referents – General comments: -ka: past form of middle
-kan: non-past form of middle
adverbial intensifier -aʔkstu reinforces verbal reflexive and is in some contexts obligatory

Only animate referents; lexical source: laa: pronominal stem, regularly shortened to la if not accented; gahk: 'exactly, right'; other intensifier: žteb: 'by itself' – General comments: the adjunct reflexive lagahk is optional; a simple pronoun can also be locally bound
General comments: Reflexive amji is invariant.

Lexical source: tɨ́: 'as'; rɔ̀: 'away from'; other intensifier: nyú̵ (also 'very') – General comments: the position of PRON/ANPH-tɨ́rɔ̀ seems to be considerably parallel to English, insofar as AVE is sentence-final and ADN is adjacent to its head NP (cf. Kutsch Lojenga 1994: 200)
the reflexive ndɨ̀- is used only in the third person; in the first and second person the regular object pronouns are used (cf. German and other European languages that do not have specialized reflexive forms in the first and second person)
lexical source of reflexive ndɨ̀-: 'skin'

Lexical source: < English self; other intensifier: soseefi: 'also' – General comments: PRO: in the third person, the oblique pronoun (en, vs. the subject pronoun a) is used; in the first and second person there is no case distinction
seefi is obligatory in combination with a preceding unbound pronominal
seefi is invariant (cf. the paradigm below)
seefi is also used in a number of other functions, e.g. as an adjective of token identity ('the same', cf. ex. 780) and as an intensifying negative polarity item ('at all', 'whatsoever'; cf. ex. 654)
alternative lexical item meaning 'own': (PRO/NP) éigi (according to Huttar & Huttar 1994: 471, eigi is preferred over seefi by younger speakers)

General comments: falapetsi is an intransitive verb and literally means 'do alone/by oneself, do (an action) without participants other than the agent(s)'
it can be used in conjunction with argument suppression to indicate reflexivity (see above).

Lexical source: < Proto-Germanic *silba – General comments: with typically self-directed verbs, the simple pronouns are used in reflexive contexts; self is gaining ground, and is becoming more obligatory with verbs denoting typically other-directed activities, acccording to Donaldson (1993: Section 8.20): "The reflexivity of verbs and their use with or without the compound pronoun in -self is something that is in a state of flux in Afrikaans." Among other things, this concerns "the use of the compound form in -self whre historically it was not required or was even considered incorrect" (Donaldson 1993: 291)

Lexical source: < Proto-Germanic *silba – General comments: zelv- inflects for case (weak adjectival inflection); however, Verbeek (1917: 90) mentions that "some writers use zelf as an invariant form, like German selbst"
